Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Modeling and Simulation in Systems Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many biological processes that underlie human health, an abundant and high quality food supply, a healthy and sustainable environment, and a renewable energy supply are complex, with multiple intertwined feedback loops. Systems biology uses mathematics and mathematical models as the key enabling technology to capture this complexity in predictive computer models that allow the efficient design of control strategies, such as the development of new drugs for a variety of human, animal, and plant diseases. There is considerable need for mathematical scientists trained in the development and application of mathematical algorithms for systems biology, and this project focuses on meeting this need. The program takes advantage of a unique research environment that brings together several ongoing programs to develop and implement mathematical algorithms for modeling, simulation, and control of molecular networks. It provides a 10-week, in-residence, intensive summer research program for U.S. citizen or permanent resident undergraduate students from around the United States and Puerto Rico. It will provide participants with a broad view of available career opportunities for mathematical scientists in academia, industry, and government. Participants will have the opportunity to expand their professional network of peers and mentors. The award is supported by the Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) and the Division of Biological Infrastructure (DBI) in the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO).

Modeling and simulation is a key technology for systems biology. The focus is on biological systems that might be organized into gene regulatory, signaling, or metabolic networks, maybe linked with spatial processes, such as translocation of molecules across cellular compartments. Various intertwined feedback and feedforward loops might be involved in the regulation of the system, linking the molecular with the systemic level. Mathematical models of various kinds are indispensable tools in the effort to understand these systems. There is a clear need for mathematical scientists whose expertise can address these complexities in innovative and rigorous ways. Career opportunities for mathematical scientists with expertise in the biosciences are plentiful in both academics and in industry, in particular in the health care field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goals of the program were to

(1) Provide a 10-week in-residence, intensive summer research program, focused on modeling and simulation in systems biology for U.S. citizens and permanent resident undergraduate students from around the United States and Puerto Rico;

(2) Provide participants with a broad view of available career opportunities for mathematical scientists in academia, industry, and government.

(3) Provide participants with opportunities to develop a professional network of peers and mentors.

A total of 26 students participated during the 3-year program, approximately evenly divided into male and female students, coming from a range of home institutions including small colleges as well as research-intensive universities. The program structure was designed to provide a professional research experience for the students, within ongoing team-based research projects.

Intellectual merit: The scientific focus of the program was on the development and use of mathematical and statistical models that capture biological processes relevant for the understanding of human disease. Computational models play an increasingly important role in this context, in part because they provide a key technology that allows the integration of heterogeneous data types across different spatial and temporal scales. Thus, participants become familiar with novel mathematical techniques, novel biology and biomedicine, and novel data types, all being integrated to understand disease, in a team-science environment.

Broader impacts: The development of a qualified workforce of mathematical and computational scientists in the life sciences in general, and in biomedicine in particular, is of increasingly urgent importance, as the demand for such experts is skyrocketing across all sectors of industry and academia. This program contributes to this goal of attracting undergraduate STEM students to quantitative biology and biomedicine. It also provides an opportunity for the project personnel involved to obtain experience in mentoring undergraduate students.

Outcomes: The program enrolled 26 participants, chosen from over 100 applicants. The main mathematical themes of the 13 research projects students participated in were:

-- construction of a mathematical model of whole-body iron metabolism, which contains mechanisms to simulate several iron-related diseases such as anemia. The model can be personalized to individual patients.

-- construction of mathematical models capturing fundamental biological processes related to cell growth. Such processes play important roles in a range of diseases, such as cancer.

-- construction of mathematical models of functional brain networks from functional MRI data. Such models result in dynamic signatures for individual patients that can be used for the classification of patients suffering from emotion regulation disorders.

-- development of novel data analysis methods for high-dimensional, multi-scale patient data, such as molecular data related to disease processes or clinical data from electronic health records.

The work resulted in 2 published papers and 3 publications in various stages of preparation or review. Participants subsequently gave over 30 oral and poster presentations at scientific conferences and other venues.

The vast majority of participants are either still completing their undergraduate program, have entered graduate school, or have completed their degree and work in a STEM field.
